hotspots.hotspot:
Head of State

The president represents the nation and performs many ceremonial roles.

Chief Executive

The president uses several tools to see that the laws of Congress are carried out, such as issuing executive orders, appointing people to important offices in the executive and judicial branches, and refusing to allow a federal department or agency to spend money Congress has appropriated.

Chief Legislator

The president has a large staff to help write legislation, and the staff also presents to Congress a suggested budget and an annual economic report.

Chief Diplomat

The president directs the foreign policy of the United States â€” negotiating treaties, making executive agreements, and recognizing foreign governments.

Commander in Chief

The president shares with Congress the power to make war. The president may also use the military to control serious turmoil in the nation caused by riots or natural disasters.

Economic Planner

The president's staff presents to Congress a suggested budget and an annual economic report.

Political Party Leader

Presidents appoint members of their party to government jobs. Political patronage rewards the people who have helped get a president elected.

scene.credits: (tr)Comstock/Getty Images, (c)Diana Walker/Time & Life Pictures/Getty Images, (bkgd)Martin Ruegner/Digital Vision/Getty Images.

hotspots.hotspot:
Cabinet Departments

The 15 Cabinet departments include the Departments of Defense, State, Treasury, Interior, Agriculture, Justice, Commerce, Labor, Housing and Urban Development, Transportation, Energy, Health and Human Services, Education, Veterans Affairs, and Homeland Security. Each department has bureaus or agencies within it. The president appoints each department's secretary, undersecretary, and assistant secretaries.

Independent Agencies

The federal bureaucracy includes more than 100 independent agencies created by Congress that are not part of the Cabinet departments. Examples of independent agencies include the Social Security Administration, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, and the Central Intelligence Agency.

Government Corporations

Some independent agencies are government corporations set up and owned by the government to perform commercial activities, such as the Tennessee Valley Authority.

Regulatory Commissions

Regulatory commissions are independent agencies that make rules for industries and businesses and bring violators of those rules to court. Regulatory commissioners do not report to the president. To keep regulatory commissions impartial, they are independent of all three branches of government.

scene.credits: (tr)Comstock/Getty Images, (c)Digital Vision/Photodisc/Getty Images, (bkgd)Martin Ruegner/Digital Vision/Getty Images.

hotspots.hotspot:
Miranda v. Arizona

Miranda v. Arizona (1966) prohibited interrogating suspects of a crime without first informing them of their rights as accused persons.

Epperson v. Arkansas

Epperson v. Arkansas (1968) prohibited banning the teaching of evolution in public school.

Gideon v. Wainwright

Gideon v. Wainwright (1963) prohibited trials of accused persons in capital cases without providing them appointed counsel.

Mapp v. Ohio

Mapp v. Ohio (1962) prohibited admitting evidence gained by illegal searches into a trial.

content.text:
The level of cooperation between Congress and the president has varied throughout history. The checks and balances system can often result in a government stalemate. The president may threaten to veto a bill, and Congress may override the veto because states or districts would benefit from the bill's passage. Politics driven by party loyalty also affect relations, especially if one party controls the White House and the other controls the House and Senate.

Congress dominated policy making the first 150 years of the Republic. Several strong presidents have challenged congressional supremacy, however. In times of crisis, Congress has given extra powers to the president. The National Emergencies Act sets procedures for how and when a state of emergency exists. The president plans the national budget, but the Congressional Budget Office provides financial expertise to analyze the budget.

hotspots.hotspot:
Mass Media

The mass media includes print and broadcast media and the Internet.

Selling Ideas

Politicians "sell" their ideas and policies to the public through news releases and briefings, press conferences, background stories, leaks, and media events.

Election Season

During election season, television greatly influences who runs for office, how candidates are nominated, and campaign advertising. Television lets candidates appeal directly to the people through advertising and political debates. TV ads also allow candidates to make their opponents look unappealing.

The Senate has a more narrow constituency than the House of Representatives.
The executive branch is the lawmaking branch of the federal government.
The system in which each government branch has its own responsibilities is called the separation of powers.
The executive branch establishes the lower federal courts.
The power to impeach judges is a legislative check on the judicial branch.
The power to declare presidential acts unconstitutional is a legislative check on the executive branch.
Enumerated powers are those specifically given to Congress by Article I, Section 8, of the Constitution.
An executive department is an independent agency that has the authority to bring violators of regulations to court.
The power of the courts to declare laws unconstitutional is known as judicial review.
